title: How to Grow Silver Queen Corn

steps.headline: Start by getting good seed; preferably a name brand.
Choose a planting area suitable for growing corn.
steps.description: The soil should be rich and loamy with good drainage for best results, and corn grows best in full sun.

steps.headline: Plant the seed about 2" deep and water thoroughly in early spring when frost is no longer expected.
steps.description: This can vary depending on your region. Seeds should be spaced about 12 inches (30.5 cm) apart to allow space for the plants.

steps.headline: Maintain the ground moisture for about 2 to 3 weeks or until seeds sprout.
When seedlings appear, give a good liquid fertilizer of choice (preferably high in nitrogen).
steps.description: Avoid contact with the plants as this can damage the delicate seedlings.

steps.headline: Keep the corn cultivated to keep the soil from compacting around the roots and to prevent weeds.
When corn is at max size, about 5 to 6 feet (1.5 to 1.8 m) in height, (shown above) fertilize again with a liquid fertilizer.
See if it's ready.
steps.description: Look at the silks on individual ears to see if they are dark brown and beginning to dry out. Pull back the husk on an ear or two to expose the uppermost kernels. You will know corn is ready when you push your finger into a kernel and white liquid comes out.

steps.headline: Pick the corn and shuck just before you cook it, and then enjoy.

text: Start by getting good seed; preferably a name brand.  Choose a planting area suitable for growing corn. The soil should be rich and loamy with good drainage for best results, and corn grows best in full sun. Plant the seed about 2" deep and water thoroughly in early spring when frost is no longer expected. This can vary depending on your region. Seeds should be spaced about 12 inches (30.5 cm) apart to allow space for the plants. Maintain the ground moisture for about 2 to 3 weeks or until seeds sprout.  When seedlings appear, give a good liquid fertilizer of choice (preferably high in nitrogen). Avoid contact with the plants as this can damage the delicate seedlings. Keep the corn cultivated to keep the soil from compacting around the roots and to prevent weeds.  When corn is at max size, about 5 to 6 feet (1.5 to 1.8 m) in height, (shown above) fertilize again with a liquid fertilizer.  See if it's ready. Look at the silks on individual ears to see if they are dark brown and beginning to dry out. Pull back the husk on an ear or two to expose the uppermost kernels. You will know corn is ready when you push your finger into a kernel and white liquid comes out. Pick the corn and shuck just before you cook it, and then enjoy.
sentences: Start by getting good seed; preferably a name brand.
Choose a planting area suitable for growing corn.
The soil should be rich and loamy with good drainage for best results, and corn grows best in full sun.
Plant the seed about 2" deep and water thoroughly in early spring when frost is no longer expected.
This can vary depending on your region.
Seeds should be spaced about 12 inches (30.5 cm) apart to allow space for the plants.
Maintain the ground moisture for about 2 to 3 weeks or until seeds sprout.
When seedlings appear, give a good liquid fertilizer of choice (preferably high in nitrogen).
Avoid contact with the plants as this can damage the delicate seedlings.
Keep the corn cultivated to keep the soil from compacting around the roots and to prevent weeds.
When corn is at max size, about 5 to 6 feet (1.5 to 1.8 m) in height, (shown above) fertilize again with a liquid fertilizer.
Look at the silks on individual ears to see if they are dark brown and beginning to dry out.
Pull back the husk on an ear or two to expose the uppermost kernels.
You will know corn is ready when you push your finger into a kernel and white liquid comes out.
Pick the corn and shuck just before you cook it, and then enjoy.
